query: What are the lesser-known legal ways for F1 international students to make money in the US? Explore: on-campus employment edge cases, CPT/OPT strategies, passive income that doesn't count as "employment", scholarships/fellowships, entrepreneurship options, and any gray areas that are technically permitted under immigration law.

R1.A.title: On-Campus Employment Edge Cases
R1.A.plannedAction: Research lesser-known on-campus employment options: bookstores, cafeterias run by third-party vendors on campus, research assistantships, university-affiliated entities, and how 'on-campus' is legally defined

R1.B.title: Passive Income Loopholes
R1.B.plannedAction: Investigate income sources that don't count as 'employment' under immigration law: stock trading, crypto, royalties, rental income from home country assets, online content monetization, selling personal property

R1.C.title: CPT/OPT Optimization
R1.C.plannedAction: Research strategies to maximize CPT usage, Day-1 CPT programs, pre-completion OPT, stacking OPT with degree changes, STEM OPT extension eligibility tricks

R1.D.title: Entrepreneurship Gray Areas
R1.D.plannedAction: Explore what F1 students CAN do: unpaid ownership, passive investment, forming LLCs for passive income, freelancing through foreign entities, the 'active vs passive' distinction

R1.E.title: Scholarships & Prize Money
R1.E.plannedAction: Research fellowship stipends, competition prize money, research grants paid directly to students, teaching assistantships with tuition waivers - income that bypasses work authorization
